newsitem.title: UK: IPE upgrades natural gas trading system.
newsitem.headline: IPE upgrades natural gas trading system.

text.p: The International Petroleum Exchange (IPE) announced on Wednesday it has made a number of changes to the Energy Trading System (ETS), the screen-based system used for trading natural gas futures.

The changes include new warnings given when bids or offers are placed significantly above or below the last traded price. When a bid is more than 0.50 pence a therm above the last traded price, the warning "limit price is significantly above last traded price" is given. For an offer more than 0.50 pence a therm below the last traded price, the system warns "limit price is significantly below last trade."
In a thin market where a traded price may not be available because no deals have been done in the period in question, the settlement price from the previous day is used as a reference.
In another change, traders will no longer be able to enter a bid higher than the best offer or enter an offer below the best bid.

"This will bring the ETS in line with current practices on the trading floor where breaking the market is not allowed," the IPE said in a statement. But traders will still be able to use the "fill down" facility from the depth of market screen to take out more then one bid or offer at a time.

The changes follow a number of occasions since the launch of the natural gas contract on January 31 when trades have been done as a result of bids or offers entered in error. There have been trades "busted" by the exchange as a result.
Trade on the IPE natural gas contract has become thin in recent weeks after a relatively busy start. Only 310 lots have been done since May 12, with no trade concluded so far this week.
